timeline.bodyText: I think the end goal is to remove any methods that are specific to a given constraint from the ConstraintFetcher interface. So I would rather mock a generic method (like getSingleConstraint) and make sure the scrunizer calls that.
timeline.author: wetneb

timeline.bodyText: Is this inner class actually used in the scrutinizer?
timeline.author: wetneb

replies.bodyText: Actually, no. Because it has just one parameter as constraint status, which we are not currently using to raise warnings. Should we consider that? then only this class makes any sense.
replies.author: darecoder

replies.bodyText:
I think it the general structure of scrutinizers should be like this:

fetch all constraint statements of a given type via the fetcher
map these to constraint definitions (.map(statement -> new MultivalueConstraint(statement)))
for each constraint definition, run the scrutinizing code

So in this case the inner class would still be "used": the scrutinizing code would just not rely on it to fetch parameters for now. In the future, when we add support for exceptions, this class will still be useful :) Or we could replace it simply by the base class that fetches generic constraint parameters, too.
replies.author: wetneb

timeline.bodyText: I would rather pass a Statement as parameter, and do the initial fetching externally. This ensures that an instance of this inner class corresponds to a constraint declaration.
timeline.author: wetneb

timeline.bodyText: When does it make sense for getConstraintsByType to return a null value in its stream? Intuitively I think these should be filtered out upstream, no?
timeline.author: wetneb

timeline.message:
New implementation for Multivalue Scrutinizer

Created inner class for Multivalue & mocks for unit tests

New implementation for multivalue scrutinizer

tests updated

timeline.bodyText: This "constraint status" property is not specific to the multi value constraint, it is applicable to all other constraint definitions, so it should rather be defined in a generic location. We can leave this as it is right now, but in the future it really ought to be used by a class that all constraint definitions inherit from.
timeline.author: wetneb
